Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome

Viral Infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C, Parvovirus B19)

Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Schizophrenia (as a cause or result of psychosis, with secondary conditions)
Chronic Kidney Disease due to Glomerulonephritis
Schizophrenia (in the context of co-occurring medical conditions)

diagnoses.diagnosis: Constitutional delay of growth and puberty
diagnoses.explanation: One of the most common causes of delayed puberty, which might be considered in absence of other significant systemic symptoms.
A group of disorders affecting connective tissues, known for hypermobility. While not directly explaining all symptoms, its systemic nature could correlate with various manifestations.
Could explain hyperferritinemia; however, other systemic symptoms would typically be present. Puberty delay could be an indirect effect of endocrine disturbances.
Systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis could cause hyperferritinemia and delay in growth/puberty. Hypermobility might be observed, though it's not a primary symptom.

Chronic infections or inflammatory conditions can delay puberty, cause hyperferritinemia due to ongoing inflammation, and affect growth. Specificity of cough and dysosmia would need further investigation.
Affects females, characterized by delayed puberty. Hypermobility can be seen. Hyperferritinemia might not be a direct correlation but could relate to associated conditions.
Affects males, with a common symptom being delayed puberty. Hyperferritinemia and hypermobility are less directly correlated but could be considered with a broad differential.

Can present with delayed puberty due to chronic systemic illness. Cough is a primary symptom. Dysosmia may be related to sinus issues. Hypermobility and hyperferritinemia are not direct symptoms but could be seen in complex clinical pictures.
Could cause various symptoms including growth delay due to chronic infection. Hyperferritinemia might reflect chronic inflammation.
May present with delayed puberty. Hypermobility isn't a direct symptom, and hyperferritinemia might be incidental or reflect associated stress or inflammation.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immune Deficiency (CVID)
diagnoses.description: CVID is a disorder characterized by low levels of several immunoglobulin classes, leading to an increased susceptibility to infections. Patients may present with symptoms like pneumonia, muscle pain, and may have autoimmune manifestations such as telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA)
diagnoses.description: GPA is a form of vasculitis that can lead to symptoms like muscle pain and decreased immunoglobulin levels. Telangiectasias and difficulties concentrating can be related to systemic inflammation or organ involvement.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: SLE is an autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, including the skin (telangiectasias), the nervous system (difficulty concentrating), the muscles (muscle pain), and the immune system (decreased immunoglobulins), leading to increased susceptibility to infections like pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)
diagnoses.description: CLL is a type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow. It can lead to decreased immunoglobulin levels, making patients more susceptible to infections like pneumonia. Telangiectasias may occur due to skin involvement.

diagnoses.name: Selective IgA Deficiency
diagnoses.description: This is the most common primary immunodeficiency, characterized by low or absent levels of immunoglobulin A (IgA). It can lead to recurrent infections like pneumonia and may present with associated autoimmune manifestations such as muscle pain.

diagnoses.name: Hypogammaglobulinemia
diagnoses.description: Hypogammaglobulinemia is a condition marked by decreased levels of immunoglobulins in the blood, leading to an increased risk of infections, including pneumonia. Muscle pain and telangiectasias may be associated with underlying conditions or secondary autoimmune responses.

diagnoses.name: Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, X-linked disorder characterized by eczema, thrombocytopenia, immunodeficiency, and recurrent infections like pneumonia. While primarily affecting males, it's associated with decreased levels of immunoglobulins and can cause symptoms like muscle pain.

diagnoses.name: Good's Syndrome (Thymoma with Immunodeficiency)
diagnoses.description: Good's Syndrome is a rare condition associated with thymomas. It features a reduced number of B and T cells and hypogammaglobulinemia, leading to increased susceptibility to recurrent infections such as pneumonia. Telangiectasias may also be present as part of the broader autoimmune spectrum.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that typically presents with dry eyes and mouth, but can also lead to systemic features such as decreased immunoglobulin levels, recurrent pneumonia, muscle pain, and neurologic complaints such as difficulty concentrating.

diagnoses.name: Graft vs Host Disease (GVHD)
diagnoses.description: GVHD is a complication of allogeneic tissue transplantation where the donated bone marrow or peripheral blood stem cells view the recipient’s body as foreign, and the immunologic attack that ensues can lead to symptoms including decreased immunoglobulins, pneumonia, muscle pain, and potentially, telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the immune system, leading to increased susceptibility to infections due to a defect in phagocytes.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disorder causing ulcers, and often affecting the eyes, skin, and genitals.

diagnoses.name: Ataxia Telangiectasia
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition characterized by progressive neurological problems, telangiectasias, and a higher risk of infections and cancer.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A chronic, potentially life-threatening condition caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), leading to a severely weakened immune system.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that provide lubrication to the eyes and other parts of the body, potentially leading to complications including depression.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect various parts of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, heart, and brain.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that affect how your body uses blood glucose, potentially leading to an increased risk of infections.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system).

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can lead to widespread inflammation affecting various body parts, including the eyes and skin, sometimes resulting in ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mood disorder causing a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest. While not a direct diagnosis for the physical symptoms, it's common for chronic illness to lead to depression.
Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: This rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes can result from medication or an infection. Hypersensitivity reactions, such as skin irritation and ocular issues, are symptomatic.

diagnoses.description: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reasoning: An autoimmune disease that affects the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. Symptoms can include hypersensitivity reactions to sunlight, leading to skin issues, and various neuropsychiatric manifestations, possibly reflecting obsessive-compulsive behaviors.

diagnoses.description: Atopic Dermatitis
diagnoses.reasoning: A long-term skin disease characterized by itchy, inflamed skin, which can lead to folliculitis and eye irritation.

diagnoses.description: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
diagnoses.reasoning: A chronic disorder in which a person has uncontrollable, reoccurring thoughts (obsessions) and behaviors (compulsions). While not directly explaining all physical symptoms, psychiatric manifestations such as OCD can exacerbate or be co-morbid with conditions leading to physical symptoms.

diagnoses.description: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Can lead to reduced metabolism and a drop in core body temperature, potentially causing hypothermia. Skin changes and psychiatric manifestations like OCD behavior could also be related.

diagnoses.description: Contact Dermatitis
diagnoses.reasoning: A red, itchy rash caused by direct contact with a substance or an allergic reaction to it, leading to hypersensitivity reactions and possibly affected skin follicles resulting in folliculitis.

diagnoses.description: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands responsible for keeping the eyes, mouth, and other parts of the body moist and lubricated, leading to dry, irritated eyes and possibly associated skin conditions.

diagnoses.description: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily psychiatric disorders, severe anxiety can precipitate obsessive-compulsive behaviors and somatic symptoms like hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.description: Primary Immunodeficiency Diseases
diagnoses.reasoning: These diseases impair the body's ability to fight infections, leading to more frequent skin infections (potentially folliculitis) and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.description: Environmental Allergies
diagnoses.reasoning: Allergic reactions to substances in the environment can provoke hypersensitivity reactions, eye irritation, and skin issues including folliculitis, as the immune system overreacts to harmless substances.

diagnoses: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) / Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS)
Graft vs Host Disease (especially in post-transplant patients)
Diabetes mellitus type 1 or 2 with poorly controlled glucose levels
Acquired angioedema (e.g., due to ACE inhibitors)

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in the blood-forming cells of the bone marrow and invades the blood. It presents with symptoms like delayed puberty due to malnutrition or direct marrow involvement, thrombocytosis (elevated platelet count), and can cause lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow that affects white blood cells. Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy and delayed puberty. It is associated with bone pain which may be related to oral pain.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma, which is a cancer that begins in cells of the immune system. Can cause symptoms such as lymphadenopathy, and possibly thrombocytosis in reactive conditions. Delayed puberty might occur due to the overall stress on the body.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A group of blood cancers that includes all types of lymphoma except Hodgkin's lymphomas. Symptoms include lymphadenopathy and possibly delayed puberty due to nutritional or systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which the body cannot properly regulate the number of immune system cells. This condition can cause lymphadenopathy, and potentially, thrombocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder affecting children that causes joint inflammation and stiffness for more than six weeks. While not directly related, systemic effects could potentially lead to thrombocytosis and delayed puberty.

diagnoses.name: Infections (Viral, Bacterial)
diagnoses.description: Certain infections can cause thrombocytosis, lymphadenopathy, and potentially impact puberty timing. Oral pain may be related to specific infections like those causing oral ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. It can cause lymphadenopathy and, in rare cases, might be associated with hypercalcemia leading to hyperactivity.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions affecting the thyroid can lead to delayed puberty and, in some cases, hyperactivity. Thyroid dysfunction can indirectly lead to oral pain, such as through changes in salivary function or calcitonin-related bone pain.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition marked by a deficiency of red blood cells or hemoglobin in the blood, leading to fatigue among other symptoms. It can be associated with oral pain due to atrophic changes in tongue or mouth ulcers and, in severe cases, might relate to delayed puberty due to overall nutritional deficiencies.

diagnoses: Dental Disorders (e.g., tooth abscess, gum disease)
Tinnitus (primary condition, or secondary to other causes like hearing loss or medications)
Acute or Chronic Infections leading to Lymphadenitis

diagnoses.name: Allergic reaction
diagnoses.description: An immune system response to a foreign substance that's not typically harmful to your body. These foreign substances are called allergens. They can include certain foods, pollen, or pet dander. Symptoms include hives, pruritis (itching), and possibly rhinorrhea (runny nose). Severe reactions can lead to hypoxia due to airway swelling.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur within seconds or minutes of exposure to an allergen. Symptoms include hives, itching, hypoxia, and trouble breathing. Immediate medical attention is required.

diagnoses.name: Urinary tract infection (UTI)
diagnoses.description: An infection in any part of the urinary system, kidneys, bladder, or urethra. While not directly causing hives or pruritis, severe or systemic infections can trigger allergic-like reactions in the body. Symptoms can include incontinence or an increased urge to urinate.

diagnoses.name: Atopic dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A condition that makes your skin red and itchy. It's common in children but can occur at any age. Atopic dermatitis is long lasting (chronic) and tends to flare periodically. It may be accompanied by asthma or hay fever, potentially explaining rhinorrhea.

diagnoses.name: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs. Symptoms include breathing difficulty, cough, mucus (sputum) production and wheezing. It can lead to hypoxia but typically does not cause hives or incontinence directly.

diagnoses.name: Heart failure
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the heart can't pump enough blood to meet the body's needs. Symptoms can include shortness of breath, fatigue, swollen legs, and very indirectly may lead to issues like incontinence due to the fluid overload and body stress.

diagnoses.name: Drug reaction
diagnoses.description: Adverse reactions to a drug can vary widely and mimic many symptoms including hives, pruritis, hypoxia, and rhinorrhea. This diagnosis should be considered especially if the onset of symptoms follows new medication.

diagnoses.name: Angioedema
diagnoses.description: An area of swelling of the lower layer of skin and tissue just under the skin or mucous membranes. The swelling may occur in the face, extremities, genitals, gastrointestinal tract, and in severe cases, the airway, potentially causing hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Contact dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A skin rash caused by contact with a certain substance. Symptoms can include a red itchy rash, blisters, dry, cracked skin, and hives. It does not directly cause hypoxia or incontinence but can be part of an allergenic response.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your airways narrow and swell and may produce extra mucus. This can make breathing difficult and trigger coughing, wheezing, and shortness of breath. Severe cases can lead to hypoxia.

diagnoses: Allergic Rhinitis (with possible accompanying asthma for wheezing)
Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) (less likely with wheezing unless asthmatic)

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, causing a range of neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain or close to it. Symptoms can vary greatly depending on the tumor's location.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: A neurological disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, causing loss of muscle control.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves, leading to muscle weakness and sometimes paralysis.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Brainstem Aura
diagnoses.description: A rare type of migraine that can affect the brainstem, causing symptoms such as vertigo, double vision, and lack of coordination.

diagnoses.name: Wilson's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare inherited disorder that causes copper to accumulate in the liver, brain, and other vital organs, leading to neurological problems.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. It can lead to neurological problems if not treated.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in the brain due to an infection or trauma. Symptoms can mimic several other neurological conditions.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache that is often accompanied by visual disturbances (such as scotoma), sensory symptoms (such as parasthesia and numbness), and sometimes difficulty speaking. These symptoms typically precede the headache phase.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving your central nervous system. The immune system attacks myelin, which is the protective layer around your nerves, leading to symptoms such as numbness, weakness, balance issues, and sensory disturbances like parasthesia.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it's a brief period of symptoms similar to those in a stroke, such as numbness or weakness, especially on one side of the body; trouble speaking; and vision problems, including scotoma. These symptoms usually last less than an hour.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Symptoms can include headaches, seizures, problems with vision such as scotoma, numbness or parasthesia in parts of the body, and other neurological symptoms depending on the tumor's location.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include headache, paralysis or numbness of the face, arms or legs, difficulties in speaking or understanding speech, and vision problems, including scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the optic nerve that can cause a reduction in vision, scotoma (loss of a portion of the field of view), pain with eye movement, and sometimes flashing lights. It may present with or lead to the development of multiple sclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes. Symptoms include numbness, tingling, or pain in the toes, feet, legs, hands, arms, and fingers. In some cases, patients might also experience visual problems like scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when your body's immune system attacks your own tissues and organs. Symptoms include fatigue, joint pain, rash, and neurological symptoms like headaches, numbness, and parasthesia.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Can lead to neurological problems such as numbness, tingling (parasthesia), difficulty walking, memory loss, and headache. Lack of B12 can damage the protective sheath that covers nerves.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known as the meninges. Symptoms include severe headache, fever, confusion, vomiting, and sometimes symptoms like numbness or weakness, which might be mistaken for parasthesia.

diagnoses: Epilepsy with visual and sensory aura

diagnoses.description: Migraines with aura are headaches accompanied by sensory disturbances that can include photophobia, scotoma (blind spots), and sometimes dysarthria or aphasia.
A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, leading to symptoms like dysarthria, parasthesia, and sometimes aphasia or photophobia.
A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include aphasia, dysarthria, and parasthesia.
An abnormal growth of cells in the brain that can cause symptoms such as aphasia, photophobia, and dysarthria depending on its location.
Often called a mini-stroke, it's a brief period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke, such as aphasia and parasthesia.
Inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms can include photophobia along with neurological deficits.
An inflammation of the brain, often caused by a viral infection, and can present with aphasia, photophobia, and dysarthria.

A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Certain types may cause visual disturbances like scotoma or aphasia.
A common type of migraine characterized by throbbing pain on one side of the head, photophobia, but typically without the visual or neurological symptoms (aura) before the headache.
A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves, leading to symptoms like parasthesia. Dysarthria and other neurological symptoms can occur as the condition progresses.

diagnoses: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD) with neurological manifestations
Autoimmune diseases (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus with CNS involvement)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Thrombocytopenia)
Viral infections (such as HIV, Hepatitis C)
Viral infections (HIV, Hepatitis C) with associated autoimmune reactions
